newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish Treasury bond yields seen down at auction.
newsitem.headline: Spanish Treasury bond yields seen down at auction.

text.p: Spain's Treasury is seen allocating more bonds than expected at its monthly refunding auctions on Tuesday and Wednesday with yields sharply lower than in April, dealers said on Monday.
Traders were expecting the Treasury to sell between 500 and 600 billion pesetas versus a target of 485 billion announced on Monday.
The bonds are expected to sell with no premium over secondary market prices.
Earlier on Monday, the three-year 6.75 percent coupon bond was trading at around 5.54 percent versus a 6.224 percent yield showed at the beginning of April.
The five-year yield was at around 5.93 percent versus 6.573 percent, while the 10-year bond was at 6.75 percent versus 7.262 percent. The 15-year was 6.98 percent versus 7.489 percent.
"The auctions this week are set to attract enough interest. The market is favourable," one dealer said "The Treasury can easily reach its target without paying any premium."
The Treasury said the maximum amount offered is between 375 billion pesetas in three- and 10-year bonds, and 225 billion pesetas in five- and 15-year.
"I think the allocation will be closest to the maximum beacuse they will take advantage of these favourable conditions" a dealer in Madrid said.
Analysts stressed Spain's Treasury is facing a heavy load of maturing paper on June and July, around 5.13 trillion pesetas.
"In June and July, the Treasury has to face heavy refinancing auctions," said Alfredo Urrutia at Societe Generale in Madrid. "So the more it can issue before, the better," he added.
From January to April, the Treasury issued in bills, notes and bonds a total of 6.4 billion pesetas.
